I agree with Rocky Anderson on the issue of the PATRIOT Act. He is a lawyer who worked on civil rights issues and was the Justice Party's presidential candidate in 2012:

“The [PATRIOT] Act is a clear and unambiguous assault on U.S. civil liberties, which is a key principle distinguishing our nation from many others. If we value the principles upon which our nation was founded, we will not let the threat of terror destroy them.

“Rocky Anderson’s Approach Toward Solutions:

“Oppose retroactive immunity for individuals or companies that have violated federal law.

“Abolish the right of federal agencies to spy on US citizens without a warrant, based upon a showing of good cause.

“Eliminate the obligation of third parties to hand over documents concerning other persons to federal agencies without a court-issued warrant.

“Abolish ‘sneak and peak’ provisions enabled by the Act; searches should only be conducted with a warrant delivered prior to the search, not subsequently (absent exigent circumstances).

“End indefinite detention of foreign and U.S. citizens; everyone has the right to charges, legal representation, habeas corpus, and a fair trial.

“With these significant changes, the U.S. can begin the process of recapturing the principles of liberty upon which it was founded, while still safeguarding the security of its citizens.”

http://www.voterocky.org/patriot_act

President Obama’s rhetoric does not match his actions. In 2008, Obama said he would “strengthen whistleblower laws to protect federal workers who expose waste, fraud, and abuse.” Instead, he has prosecuted more whistleblowers under the Espionage Act than previous presidents combined (including NSA whistleblower Thomas Drake who was prosecuted for exposing the expensive Trailblazer program over another program which had “built-in privacy protections").

More examples of President Obama saying one thing and doing another: While Obama talks about dealing with issues like global warming, the minimum wage, and strengthening the middle class, he takes an all-of-the-above approach on energy, he has failed to use the bully pulpit to garner support for raising the minimum wage, and he is pushing cuts to Social Security and austerity instead of highlighting the need for more stimulus to create jobs. But the Democrats prefer to be Republican-lite and serve the interests of the 1 percent.

And on the issue of transparency, negotiations for the Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement are being conducted in secret. This agreement has very little to do with trade. If the TPP is approved it will erode protections in domestic laws and give radical new powers to multinational corporations when it comes to labor issues, environmental and safety standards, land-use rules, public health, food safety, financial regulations, and more.

http://www.citizen.org/documents/Leaked-TPP-Investment-Analysis.pdf

The bottom line is that the American People have no real options. In 2016 , or 2024 , or whenever people finally block the noise and realize that both parties and the politicians who front for them really don't care about anything but the interests of the wealthy who have real options in this life, the people with the options will have the greatest array of intelligence gathering tools at hand to ferret out those people who are agitating for meaningful change.

East Germany could not dream of this level of surveillance. I have no doubt that this technology will be used against people or groups labelled by those in power as domestic terrorists

At least we won't hear a soldier fighting our next war saying that he or she is putting their life on the line fighting to preserve privacy. And , without privacy, there is no freedom.
If ever there does emerge a new "deep squeak" he or she will be sent to a government re-education camp and emerge as a zombie lobbyist for some obscure extinct species.

Yes, yes, there are those pesky constitutional concerns about the right to privacy.

But at last we can mine the telephony metadata for vital national security interests.

The "real" conversations between Gov. Scott Walker and one or both of the Koch Brothers Incorporated can finally hit the airwaves. No more pranking required to get the low-down on the lowest-down of the politico-corporate cronies snatching away our democracy. An unholy alliance of hot billions and cold hearts revealed.

An added bonus: all of Mitch McConnell's tele-phony chicanery revealed (why does telephony conjure up seances ? political telepathy ?).

Now to find a skilled leaker. A rising profession in these dark and deep political waters.

The steel can be recycled by mixing with other scrap steel so that the radioactivity will be below the legal limit. Then it can be sold as recycled steel. The reactor vessel is a huge amount of stainless steel.

We don't recycle nuclear fuel because it is valuable and people steal it. The place it went that it wasn't supposed to go to is Israel. This happened in a small town near Pittsburgh, PA circa 1970. A company called Numec was in the business of reprocessing nuclear fuel.

[I almost took a job there in 1968, designing a nuclear battery for a heart pacemaker. [A nuclear battery would have the advantage of lasting many times as long as any other battery, eliminating many surgeries to replace batteries.]]
Spent fuel should be recycled, not stored.
Numec did not have a reactor. Numec "lost" some nuclear fuel. It wound up in Israel. The Israelis fueled their nuclear short cycle plutonium239 plant to make their nuclear weapons by stealing nuclear "waste."

The problem is political: The Republicans think GOGO plants are socialist/communist, which is nonsense. If a COCO [Contractor Owned Contractor Operated] plant is the low bidder, it is inevitably a front for Israel or some other country. We could send our spent fuel to France, Japan or Russia to be recycled.

Did somebody say bad clue?

"Des" can mean "from the," of course. But sometimes the definite article is used in French but not in English, so "des" would become "from." For instance, "hands" are always "les mains," so "from hands to mouth" is "des mains à la bouche."

Just remember that the best clue on Saturday is probably not a clue that Fact Boy would like.

'Des' is the male/neuter german genitive
article, so it means 'of the', i.e. 'from'.

Almost Naticked by SEGER x UNGAVA. SEGER turned out to be the correct guess. LAALAA I got only from the crossings. ED SULLIVAN was an early gimme.

DES (de les) had a bad clue in that it means "from the." That's the second time this year for this faux pas. On 02/23/13 it was defined simply as a preposition when it is really "une forme contractée sans apostrophe." DEL would have fit 10d. for the same reason, although it is a contraction of "de el."

Did you ask him why he didn't just wait in the bathroom for his friend to get home? I mean, not like he would be trapped in there for a week. Something a little dodgy about that whole thing. Brutal outcome, though.

Liam, its pretty hard to digest your argument when you start with such a faulty premise that because "it" didn't stop your list of killers/terrorists or prevent many incidents that it hasn't stopped others.  Or that it won't in the future or that it has no uses otherwise?  Isn't it like the national (almost) databank of fingerprints (mine was obtained by routine when I was in boot camp 40 years or so ago) - that data bank has never caused me woe but has helped immensely in dealing with crime and the justice system.  Not to say it didn't stop all those killers you listed, but come on, that wasn't its purpose.

Maybe another consideration. If "they" tell us how they successfully stop terrorist attacks the terrorist just adapts. So it makes some sense to keep the methods more secret as long as they work. Really a rock and a hard place. We want to hope these extra security measures have worked, but how can they tell us about it for fear it will make it harder for them to do the job?. And how can they tell us what we don't know yet?

Police state? Yeah, most likely coming more and more. People are already divided around the middle on it. Sure when something happens the voters polled get fickle. That's typical. Left or Right voters have to decide how they want their government to run. But Independents really need to make up their mind. They've seen nearly 40 yrs of failed economic policies. What more do they need to know about republican policies? Maybe they agree with some.

But somehow greed, old hatreds, and just plain power hunger overshadow what voters could decide. Even if the voters could. Look at the divide between solid gop and solid dem states. We've all agreed to agree that red and blue states can no way get along. Calls for secession. This should really be telling voters there's some other force here pushing this divide. And why would we fight our own people just because they may have a job with benefits? When we used to have benefits but then our jobs went to China we lost those, and now we work part time at WalMart.

I hate to break it to you, but yes, we do allow someone to follow us around recording everything we do, everything we look at, everyone we talk to. Anyone with a smartphone and a Facebook account is doing exactly that, entirely of their own free will. Google is tracking your every move, sending you ads based on where you are going, what you've been searching and reading, and what you've been saying in your emails and social media posts. Your family photo album, your documents at work, and that novel you're writing are all sitting somewhere in "the Cloud," and you put them there yourself.

Privacy is dead and buried, and we pulled the trigger ourselves.

Did this enable us to stop the Boston Marathon bombers, the Army Major in thrall to Islamic terrorists who murdered many soldiers, the underwear bomber, the Times Square bombing attempt? Did all this data gathering enable us to stop the Newtown murderer, the Colorado theater murderer, the Gifford murderer, the Virginia Tech murderer?

No, no, and no over and over again. So just what is this NSA for? Techie welfare?

The Guardian's leaked document was marked Top Secret/SI/NOFORN. The SI means signal intelligence. That's the easy material to collect. However, there's an old adage in the intelligence business, "It's easy to tell something is going on. The hard part is to figure out why."

Figuring out why often relies on human intelligence - that's the hard job. Yet, the CIA, who should be doing that, has been enthrall to their drone toys - also the easy part.

Repeal the Patriot Act, collect data only on those under suspicion and only with a warrant, and hold collected data only ten years unless being actively used.

Would we allow someone to follow us around recording all whom we talked to, in and out of our homes, cars, in business discussions, and all of our web interactions? Of course not. Not being able to see them doing it doesn't make it allowable, either.

Disgusting. But, are we going to do more than just beat our breasts, rant, and whine?
patterns and content are two different things. sucking up phone and online content now. also, cell phones are tracking devices, and so richer more descrptive patterns are now interpretable.

I agree.
I'm quite uneasy over the collection of data, and want more proof of safeguards for American citizens. I'm concerned about government overreach. But I don't want to see President Obama demonized over this as something he unleashed on the country. The NSA has been collecting data for decades. Obama;s involvement is no more or no less than every President we have had since this practice began. And I do believe the President in 2006 was G.W. Bush.
Now Vice President Cheney? The whole Patriot Act reeks of him.
Better late than never.

By Leslie Cauley, USA TODAY 5/11/2006

The National Security Agency has been secretly collecting the phone call records of tens of millions of Americans, using data provided by AT&T, Verizon and BellSouth, people with direct knowledge of the arrangement told USA TODAY.

The NSA program reaches into homes and businesses across the nation by amassing information about the calls of ordinary Americans — most of whom aren't suspected of any crime. This program does not involve the NSA listening to or recording conversations. But the spy agency is using the data to analyze calling patterns in an effort to detect terrorist activity, sources said in separate interviews.

Note the date on that story and ask yourself why you are outraged now when this has been going on since, well.....
http://yahoo.usatoday.com/news/washington/2006-05-10-nsa_x.htm
Sounds beautiful!

Ignoring the sarcasm, that is not an irrational response. If you are concerned about your privacy in communications or internet activity, you can opt out, or reduce it.
We have couriers. USPS.
Hopefully, we're not all murderers and no one cares to hunt us down.

We should unsubscribe from the NYT and all other media; Cancel our phone service, and live off the grid. Find a courier, like Osama bin Laden did, so we won't be monitored. Wait, that didn't work out too well for Osama, did it?

Yup.

However, the first step needed to wind any of this machinery down is the acquisition of s spine by the public. The world is unpredictable and full protection against harm is impossible. This apparently is too awful a truth for some people to accept, and politicians have exploited the fearful by holding out the false promise of safety "if only we do X ...".

The day politicians are convinced we're no longer motivated by blind, irrational fear, they'll stop stoking it and we can figure out more constructive ways of spending our time and money.

The system is designed to discover nefarious behavior and cyber attacks on infrastructure, the communications systems itself, and other public and private targets.  Hopefully it can also intercept these attacks in time.

California's DMV wastes $90 Million, Florida $200 Million on software databases that didn't work, not to mention construction costs wasted to fix problems on the Big Dig in Boston and now the Bay Bridge in the Bay Area. Soon we'll be talking real taxpayer money.

This is just the tip of the iceberg.

Within the past year, PBS aired a documentary that investigated our anti-terrorism spying apparatus. It determined that our spying machinery is so big, so vast and so secret, that no one in the government knows how big, vast and secret it is. The thing has taken on a life of its own. It's like a monster that is feeding off government revenue and constantly growing from the nourishment. It is so secret and open ended, that there is no way to even determine where the money goes. It can't even be audited.

Many tens of billions flow into this burgeoning parasite. It gets what ever it wants. It accumulates so much data that it's like a hyper google.

What do we get for this enormous expense and intrusion? Not much. Observant and watchful eyes from the public and law enforcement have shown to be the best tools we have for preventing terrorism.

This is about big business and big money- not security. It's like enforcing marijuana laws that no one wants. Too many make a living off of the enforcement for it to cease. Wind it down. Pursue real leads. Use human intelligence instead of high profit algorithms and acres of super computers. Reduce funding to the espionage-industrial complex. Leave us alone.

The only thing worse than the so-called celebrities whose personal misfortunes are reported and analyzed ad infinitum are the people who get paid good money to do the reporting and the analyzing.  Ever watch the CBS daytime show, The Talk?  The first half of the show involves ridicule, criticism and "advice" directed at people like the Kardashians, the Lohans, Paris Jackson (!) and Bobby Christina Brown (!!) by two women who are famous because their husbands are famous, a one-time actress who appeared in a hit TV show 20 years ago and two people no one had ever heard of until they were cast on this show.  In other words, people who are famous for doing nothing commenting on other people who are famous for doing nothing.

Obama became the president and drank the Koolaide the Security team, the CIA and the Pentagon provided. Now he is suffering from epistemic closure.

The terrorist threats we face are about on par with the gun violence we face and tolerate on a daily basis. However there is a difference the buildup of the security state has enriched many and the status quo on guns is enriching many.

The problem is that by allowing the creation of secret laws, secret interpretations of the laws and secret courts, we the people have no way to provide our input. Having all three branches of government sign off on a system with no public oversight is un-American and has obviously lead to cases where defense lawyers can't even see evidence their clients are being charged on and convicted by. This is a bit more than an "inconvenience" this is a tragedy in the making.

We should first dispense with this notion of the NSA being the National Security Agency. It is well known about Washington, and its suburbs (including one near Glen Echo, where there is an unmarked, gargantuan, totally-out-of-place building bristling with antennae) that there is No Such Agency.

Privacy on the web? Fuhgedaboudit!

". . . we live in a world where you can e-mail your husband about buying new kitchen curtains and then magically receive an online ad from a drapery company."

I went on a Google search for parts for a family heirloom, a 1947 International Harvester Farmall tractor. For two weeks, the front page of my link to the grey lady featured a very colorful, animated advert for their successor, Case International.

The tractor featured in the ad is FAR larger than anything I'd ever have use for and frankly, of no interest.

So much for the effectiveness/efficacy of mining internet data.

Is it not possible that every new president suddenly becomes privy to a lot of very scary intelligence issues only after they are sworn in? Probably the first big meeting of that day. No matter what they campaign on they never have all the information until later. I suspect what they learn would scare the heck out of most people. I say most people because Bush II didn't seem too concerned with all the briefings he was given about pre-9/11 situations. If he was we sure didn't know about it, and he sure didn't do what he may have been able to do to stop it. Maybe he just couldn't believe his Saudi "brothers" could do something like that.

Maybe I hope someday the justifications for Bush's foray into Iraq at the expense of chasing Bin Laden becomes apparent. Not likely. Where the heck was congress then? Where was Darrell Issa and his kind? Others like him? Even the author of the Patriot Act says he was concerned. Why didn't he write it to address his concerns? Of course he likely didn't actually write the bill. I'm sure lobbyists did that. Seems they couldn't see beyond the end of Bush II.

Does this 6% approval rating congress even realize how low they rate?
I don't feel sorry for him.  I could be a much better job as President, and I'm a nearly seventy year old retired woman.  But I'm not spineless, and I do have principles.
He didn't create the regime; Bush did.

I voted for President Obama twice. He is an incredibly smooth fellow and let's face it, his competition in both races was anything but. Then we realized in the first term that he'd changed significantly from the fellow who campaigned in 2008 for transparency and had arguably made a Faustian bargain flexing his muscles for the right wing with his tough drone program. He didn't reverse Bush's Patriot Act assaults on freedom nor speak up against indefinite detention. Is it any surprise then that we now find he has created the secret spy regime a Hitlerian tyrant would die for?

I felt a little sorry for him today, standing there arguing on the fly that he welcomed this debate. He meandered and equivocated. He stammered slightly and was more than a little hesitant. You have to believe he would like that session back. Yes, I'm almost certain that the constitutional law professor wouldn't sanction an argument that welcomed a debate only made possible by a whistleblower who his underlings are chasing at this very moment.

Just the point I was going to make. The Tsarnaevs were internet savvy, as far as I know, and Tamerlan was NOT a US citizen. So not only did we not have enough information to prevent the bombings - we didn't have a clue about the Tsarnaevs, until they were identified from photos and caught by their completely amateurish incompetence.

I have no interest, financial or otherwise, in the nuclear power industry. My only interest is in stopping Global Warming. My only income is from the US civil service retirement system.

I have no interest, financial or otherwise, in the electric utility industry, except that I buy electricity from the local utility.

If you actually do the math, as the electric utility industry has, you will find out that nuclear is the only replacement for fossil fuels that actually works.

My nuclear experience is at the army's lab for nuclear weapons effects, specifically EMP. That was a long time ago. I switched to working on weapons that kill fewer people at a time. I had something to do with getting robots into on-the-ground missions. I wanted to be able to give a war without "blood and gore," as the song says.
If Paul Ryan ever becomes President, it will be of some chain of payday loan stores, where he can fully apply his fiscal expertise.

"And yes, such invasion of privacy does (and has) saved lives."
You believe this just because the government says so, or are you indulging in sarcasm?
There certainly won't be a President Paul Ryan.

As smug and sure as most people are on this issue (on both sides) this is actually a tough one. My first instinct is that it's horrible, and that if our privacy is gone and big brother eternally watching, then, as they say, "the terrorists have won".
But this is an age with nuclear weapons. New York City can be wiped out with just one, and then all these arguments are moot, aren't they? And yes, such invasion of privacy does (and has) saved lives. The question is at what cost?

Without a free press, we're finished. But if terrorists (or two guys in Boston) get their hands on a nuclear device (it's not so ridiculous a thought anymore) we're literally finished.

The obvious answer is putting strict limits on such invasion of privacy. And under President Obama, that may or may not happen.

It certainly won't happen under President Paul Ryan.

Judges for the FISA court are picked by the Chief Justice of the Supreme court. This  particular Justice was picked by Rehnquist.

How many billions to it take to catch Zazi and how many innocent Americans privacy was compromised? NSA's failures are legion and the successes claimed relatively low level. What you mostly get are million of false leads that waste valuable FBI time.

When is a half truth a lie? Yes the NSA aren't listening to your conversations (maybe) but with the data they get they can get your name (if you ever put your phone number on a form) and your physical location when you made the call - from that they can find where you live, work, worship, whether you have a lover etc

How comforting is it that a judge approves the spying on your telephone call when the judge approved spying on all Verizon customers in the USA? Can't imagine any honest determination of relevancy or need could be made from such a mass invasion of privacy.
Through the end of 2004, 18,761 warrants were granted, while just five were rejected (many sources say four). Fewer than 200 requests had to be modified before being accepted.These judges are rubber stamps; so is the President and Congress.
